Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Example: kăt weʌpəs-χǫ jăχa-wǫjtan-s-əŋən, …;two hunt-man together-meet-PST-3DU;Two hunters met;|păʌ-ŋəʌam, păʌ-ŋəʌam, mŭj wer-s-ətən?; ear-DU<1SG ear-DU<1SG what do-PST-2DU;My (two) ears, my (two) ears, what did you do?;

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Example: jak-χɔt-teʌ mir ńăχ-ʌ-ət;dance-house-full people.SG laugh-PRS-3PL;All the people in the house laughed;|ij kǫr’-n̥ kăt xǫ wǫs-ŋǝn;a village-LOC two man live.PST-3DU;There lived two men in a village;

Name: Can finite verbs agree in number with the nominal object?
Example: ăs-śiśki wǫn̥ʌtǝ-ʌ-ʌe , aśeʌ-śiśki ʌawǝʌ-ʌ-ǝʌe;mother-bird teach-PRS-SG<3SG father-bird guard-PRS-SG<3SG;The mother bird teaches it, the father bird guards it;|tăm-pŭš nemasija ʌetŏt-ʌǝmǝn păsan-a xăj-ʌ-ǝʌʌam;this-time deliberately food-PL<31PL table-LAT leave-PRS-PL<1SG;This time I leave our food on the table deliberately;

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Are there cases that do not show agreement in terms of case?
Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can adpositions be used to mark non-core/oblique verbal arguments?
Example: nawrǝmǝ-s nŭw χŭwat ʌaŋki;spring-PST.3SG branch along squirrel;A squirrel sprang along a branch;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (S/A) marking?
Example: aśe-ʌ tăj-ǝm ʌăχǝr ʌŭweʌa mă-s, ...;father-3SG have-PTCP.PST armour 3SG.DAT give-PST.3SG;He gave him the armour that was owned by his father;|χǫ măn-ǝm χǫj-ǝŋ sŭŋ kăš-ti măn-ʌ-ǝm;man walk-PTCP.PST man-DER.ADJ corner look.for-INF go-PRS-1SG;I leave in order to look for a region inhabited by men;|mŭj ar χŏjat-n ɔms-ǝm χɔt-ew, mŏʌti wǫʌ ki, kim at măn-ǝʌ!;what many person-LOC sit-PTCP.PST house-1PL something be.PRS.3SG out IMP go-PRS.3SG;No matter by how many people our house has been inhabitated, if there is something (in it) let it go out!;

Name: Can non-finite clauses entail a special way for a core argument (P) marking?
Do characteristics of object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does the marking of the object depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e. act as syntactic pivot?
Is there a grammatical device for habituality?
Is there a grammatical device for frequentative?
Example: jăŋχ- : jăŋχijǝʌ-;;go : go frequently;

Name: Is there a grammatical device for progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Example: mănʌamǝn, wɔš-a ma măn-ʌ-ǝm; come.on town-LAT go-PRS-1SG;Come on, I will go to the town;

Name: Is there a grammatical device for immediate future?
Is there a grammatical device for pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly on the negative marker?
Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of desire or wish?
Is there morphological marking for irrealis (e.g. hypothetical state of affairs)?
Are verbs marked in a specific mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 3Sg?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to express indirect commands/wishes etc. directed to the 1Sg?
Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there reflexive conjugation?
Are there syntactically ditransitive verbs?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Example: mă-ʌ-ʌǝn;give-PRS-SG<2DU, give-PRS-SG<3DU, give-PRS-SG<2PL, give-PRS-DU/PL<2DU, give-PRS- DU/PL <3DU, give-PRS- DU/PL <2PL;;|χɔt-ǝn: house-SG<2DU, house-SG<3DU, house-SG<2PL;;|χɔt-ŋəʌǝn;house-DU<2DU, house-DU<3DU, house-DU<2PL;|χɔt-ʌǝn;house-PL<2DU, house-PL<3DU, house-PL<2PL;

Name: Can an impersonal (or passive) form be used instead of a finite plural form with an overt subject expression?
Can third person plural verb forms be used for impersonal reference?
Can second person singular verb forms be used in generic meaning?
Are clauses with only infinitive predicates possible?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be in bare infinitive form?
Example: χǫ măn-ǝm χǫj-ǝŋ sŭŋ kăš-ti măn-ʌ-ǝm;man go-PTCP.PST man-DER.ADJ corner look.for-INF go-PRS-1SG;I go to look for a region inhabited by men;

Name: Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments (e.g. weather verbs)?
Example: pătʌǝ-s;become.dark-PST.3SG;It became dark;|jɛrtǝ-ʌ;be.raining-PRS.3SG;It is raining;

Name: Is copula needed for predicate nominals in the 3rd person form of the present tense?
Is a copula needed for predicate nominals in the past and/or future tense?
Example: aśe-ʌ wŭʌi ʌawǝʌ-ti χǫ wǫs;father-3SG reindeer guard-PTCP.PRS man be.PST.3SG;His father was a reindeer herder;

Name: Can locative adverbial phrases act as predicates without a copula?
Example: năŋ pɛše-n tăta;2SG reindeer-2SG here;Your reindeer is here;
Comment: In certain cases, there is a copula: in nɛŋ-en mil nǫmn wǫʌ (DET woman-2SG cap on.top be.PRS.3SG) ’This woman’s cap is on top’.

Name: Can the same coordinating conjunction be used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Example: aj mɔś neŋ-ije pa pŏr ne-le wǫʌ-ʌ-ǝŋǝn;little mɔś woman-DIM and little pŏr woman-DIM live-PRS-2DU;There lives a mɔś-woman and a little pŏr-woman;|ij χɔta jŏχt-s-ǝt pa χǫʌǝm nŏri tăj-ǝʌ;one house arrive-PST-3PL and three bed have-PRS.3SG;They arrived at a house and it has three beds;
Comment: In traditional Khanty, coordinating conjunction is rare.

Name: Does existential negation have a separate operator?
Example: ninan păʌtaptijǝʌ-ti ŏt-ǝn ŭše ăntǫm;2DU.ACC frighten-PTCP.PRS thing-2DU already NEG.EXIST;The thing that always frightened you doesn’t exist any longer;

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Example: mănem ăn mɔs-ti χŏjat ke jŏχt-ǝs, sej tăχtaŋ χăr-ǝʌ-a măṇš-aʌn̥;1SG.DAT NEG be.likeable-PTCP.PRS man if arrive-PST.3SG sand piece-DER.ADJ place-3PL-LAT tear-IMP.SG<2DU;If I don’t like the man who arrived, tear him into so small pieces like sand;

Name: Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Example: ij at-ǝŋ χătǝʌ măr sŏrm-a jŭw-ǝm χŏjat jŏʌǝn tăj-ʌ-a;one night-DER.ADJ day time death-LAT become-PTCP.PST person at.home have-PRS-PASS.3SG;The dead body is kept at home for a whole day;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms specialized on the relativization of particular core participants, e.g. subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials, instruments, etc.?
Are there nonfinite forms that can relativize at least some noncore participants, e.g. locative adverbials or instruments, but cannot relativize all or some of the core participants, e.g. subjects?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negation marker?
Is there a future participle?
Are there participles that can encode their subject by possessive suffixes?
Example: škola-ja jŏχǝt-m-em-ǝn ńawrem-ǝt jŏχǝt-ti pit-ʌ-ǝt;school-LAT arrive-PTCP.PST-1SG-LOC child-PL arrive-INF start-PRS-PL;After I arrive at scool, children (also) start to arrive;

Name: Can subject in at least some participial subordinate clauses be encoded in the same way as in independent clauses?
Example: a ʌŭw χǫʌmit ŭw-m-aʌ-n…;but 3SG third cry-PTCP.PST-3SG-LOC;But when he cried for the third time…;

Name: Are there participles that obligatorily agree with the nouns they modify in case and number (in all contexts)?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Example: χănneχǫ sŏrm-a ji-ti jŭpijǝn…; person death-LAT become-PTCP.PRS after;after the person died, …;|... ăʌmǝnti-ki sŏrm-a ji-ti xănnexǫ pa tǫrǝm-ǝn wǫʌ-ti pit-ǝʌ;as-if death-LAT become-PTCP.PRS person other heaven-LOC live-INF start-PRS.3SG;...as if the dying person went to live in another world;

Name: Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Are there nonfinite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs without any additional morphological material, such as case markers?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Example: aj mɔś-xu, mănem jiŋk tŭw-a!;little mɔś man 1SG.DAT water bring-IMP.2SG;Little mɔś man, bring me water!;

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Comment: Usually the negative marker and the main verb are not separated, e.g. ʌapǝtmit săχ-ǝʌ aʌ ɛŋχ-e, …! (seventh fur.coat-3SG NEG.IMP take.on-SG<2SG) ’Don’t take on his seventh fur coat!’.

Name: Are there preverbs?
Example: nŏχ pit-ǝs šăš-kišǝŋ iki;up fall-PST.3SG back-hunched old.man;It is the hunchbacked old man that won (lit. fell up);

Name: Are there verbal prefixes?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalization in agent and patient roles both be marked like possessors?
Can the modifier of action nominalization in patient role (e.g. "drinking of coffee") be marked like the direct object?
Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Example: ńawrɛm-ʌaʌ isa sɔrm-ǝt, isa jăm-ǝt;child-PL<3SG all dry-PL all good-PL;Her children are all dry, they are all well;

Name: Is it possible to form synthetic superlative?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Example: min năŋ χŏśe-n-a măn-ʌ-amǝn;1DU 2SG to-2SG-LAT go-PRS-1DU;We (dual) will go to you;

Name: Are there separate adpositions to express goal, source, and location (without there being syncretism)?
Comment: In the North Khanty nominal paradigm there are only NOM, LOC, LAT cases. Source is expressed with the postposition ewǝʌt 'from', e.g. cf. ŏsǝm iʌpijn 'inside the pillow', ŏsǝm iʌpija 'into the pillow' and ŏsǝm iʌpi ewǝʌt 'from the pillow'.

Name: Is case compounding possible?
Are there case categories only found in pronouns?
Example: ma;1SG.NOM;I|mănǝt;1SG.ACC;me;|mănem(a);1SG.DAT;to me;
Comment: In the North Khanty nominal paradigm there are only NOM, LOC, LAT cases (e.g. χɔt ’house.NOM’, χɔt-a 'house-LAT', χɔt-ǝn 'house-LOC). Regarding personal pronouns, there are NOM, ACC, DAT cases.

Name: Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals bigger than 1?
Example: ij iki;one old.man;one old man|kăt pelǝk;two side;two sides|;χǫʌǝm χǫ;three man;three men;

Name: Is there a genitive case that has an affix?
Is there a dative case used to express indirect object/receiver/goal (different from a local case)?
Is there a terminative case?
Is there a separate case to indicate without what/who an action takes place / does not take place?
Is there a separate case to mark the motion along or by the referent of the noun (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that marks goal?
Example: χǫʌmit χɔt-a jŏχt-ǝs;third house-LAT arrive-PST.3SG;he arrived at the third house;

Name: Is there a locative case that marks location?
Example: jŏʌǝn nŏrij-n mŏʌti ɔmǝs-ʌ;inside bed-LOC something sit-PRS.3SG;Inside, something is sitting on the bed;

Name: Is there a locative case that marks source?
Is there case syncretism of goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism of location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Is there a third set of local cases?
Is there a separate case for marking the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniement (comitative)?
Is there a separate case for marking accompaniment, which is different from the instrumental?
Is there a separate case for marking the result of change (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Is there a separate case for marking the state of being (essive), which is different from the translative?
Is there a separate morphological marker for expressing equative meaning?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there in addition to the basic declension a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use singular with paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Example: ʌŭw sɛm-ǝʌ-a ăn pit-ǝʌ, śi sɛŋk-ǝʌ;3SG eye-SG<3SG-LAT NEG fall-PRS.3SG PTL strike-PRS.3SG;Although he can’t see (it) (lit.: it doesn’t fall into his eye), he keeps on striking;

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Can the possessor in the attributive construction be marked with the nominative?
Example: ăŋkɛ-m aśi;mother-1SG father;my mother’s father;|tăťana ť imofejewna aśi;T.T. father;T.T’s father;

Name: Is non-singular possession marked in the possessive declension?
Example: xɔt-em;house-SG<1SG;my house;|xɔt-ŋǝʌam;house-DU<1SG;my two houses;|xɔt-ʌam;house-PL<1SG;my houses;

Name: Can 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Example: tŭt-en nŏχ ăʌ-e!;fire-2SG PREV light-IMP.SG<2SG;Get the fire going!;

Name: Can 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Example: kŭrk-ǝʌ pa iśi tăχe-ʌ-a śi măn-s;eagle-3SG in-turn similarly place-3SG-LAT PRT go-PST.3SG;Similarly, the eagle has gone to her own place;

Name: Is there animacy distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Example: χŏj;;who;|mŭj;;what;

Name: When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for animates other than humans?
When used as a relative pronoun, is it common to use 'who' for inanimates?
Can a demonstrative stem be used in the function of a pronoun with 3rd person singular human referent?
Is the order of possessive suffix and case suffix across the paradigm the same?
Example: χɔp-em-ən;boat-1SG-LOC;in my boat;

Name: Is the order of number and case suffixes fixed across the paradigm the same?
Example: pănt-ət-a;path-PL-LAT;to the paths|pŏχ-ʌaʌ-a;son-PL<3SG-LAT;to his sons;

Name: Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Example: wǫrti;;younger brother of the mother;|jaj;;younger brother of the father, elder than Ego;|apśi;;younger brother of the father, younger than Ego;

Name: Are there different words for younger and older relative for other relations than siblings?
Example: imi;;elder sister of the mother of Ego;|nij;;younger sister of the mother of Ego;

Name: Is there animacy distinction for both concepts 'new/young' and 'old'?
Example: aj : pirəś;;young : old (+anim);|jiʌəp : katra;;new vs. old (–anim);

Name: Is there distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' based on whether referring to weather or to temperature of objects?
Is there contrastive length of consonants?
Is there contrastive length of vowels?
Example: wɔj ’animal’, wŏj ’fat, lard’
Comment: In the Kazym dialect, unlike in other North Khanty  dialects, not only the quantity, but also the quality of the corresponding vowels are different.

Name: Is there contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Is there contrast in duration of geminate consonants?
Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Example: katra [kaːtra] 'old', wǫnt [βɵːnt] 'forest'

Name: Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Example: piri [ˈpi.riˑ] ’a kind of wild duck’

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Example: păˈsan-ən table-LOC, wetˈraj-ət-ɑ bucket-PL-LAT, aˈnas-ət-a caravan.of.sledges-PL-LAT, păt'ʌam-a dark-LAT

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there rising diphthongs?
Are there lowering diphthongs?
Is there qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Example: kŭr ’foot, leg’ vs. kǫr ’stove’
Comment: In the Kazym dialect, unlike in other North Khanty dialects, not only the quantity, but also the quality of the corresponding vowels are different.

Name: Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Is there front high rounded vowel ü [y]?
Is there front midhigh rounded vowel ö [ø]?
Is there back high unrounded vowel ï [ɯ]?
Is there back midhigh unrounded vowel ë [ɤ]?
Is there back low round vowel [ɒ]?
Is there contrast between low and mid front vowels (ä [æ] vs. e [e])?
Comment: They are allophones, however, they are often differentiated in both the Cyrillic alphabet and in phonetic transcriptions.

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Are there word-internal consonant clusters in syllable onset?
Are there consonant clusters in syllable coda?
Are there clusters of three or more consonants in a word between vowels?
Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized dentals?
Are there palatalized labials and velars?
Is there palatal stop [c]?
Is there palatal nasal [ɲ]?
Example: ńar ’raw’, ńɔʌ ’arrow’

Name: Is there palatal lateral [ʎ]?
Example: ʌ̓awət- ’scold’, ʌ̓aʌ̓əs- ’make war’

Name: Is there phonemic velar nasal [ŋ]?
Example: mŭŋ ’we’, jaŋ ’ten’

Name: Is there dental affricate [t͡s]?
Is there non-alveolar affricate (e.g. [t͡ʃ], [͡cɕ])?
Is there a phonological contrast between [s] and postalveolar sibilant [ʃ]?
Example: šaj 'tea’ vs. saj ’place behind something’
Comment: In the Kazym Khanty dialect there is a distinction between these two sibilants. However, it is not true of all the northern dialects. In the northernmost one (Obdorsk Khanty), there is no š.

Name: Are there voiced plosives [b, g, d]?
Is there glottal stop [ˀ]?
Is there phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g. [k] vs. [kʷ])?
Is there a constraint on word-initial r?
Is there laryngeal fricative [h]?
Is there voiced velar fricative [ɣ]?
Is there voiceless velar fricative [x]?
Example: χɔp 'boat'

Name: Is there voiced dental fricative [ð]?
Is there phonemic labio-velar approximant [w]?
Is there voiceless labiodental fricative [f]?
Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
